column1: Ede (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈeːdə] (listen)) is a municipality and a city in the center of the Netherlands
The town itself is situated halfway between the larger cities of Arnhem and Utrecht
column2: with direct rail and road connections to both cities. There are no connections to any water nearby; however
column3: there also is a direct road connection to the city of Wageningen which hosts a small industrial port on the river Rijn and a direct road and rail connection to the city of Arnhem
column4: which features a larger port at a greater distance. The environment is clean and green due to the fact that Ede is partly built in a forest and partly on the central Dutch plains in the national park called Nationaal Park "De Hoge Veluwe".

column2: the town of Ede is doing fairly well thanks to the proximity of major highways and railways which offer fast connections to the port of Rotterdam
column3: Schiphol airport and the Ruhr Area in Germany. The main sources of employment used to be a factory belonging to the Dutch Enka company and the three military bases situated in the east of the town. The factory
column5: has been closed and the military bases are largely underused since conscription was abolished. The town's economy is lately becoming more focused on national tourism from the more densely populated western cities like Amsterdam and Den Haag
column6: and on education such as local colleges and the large Wageningen University in the city of Wageningen.

column1: Some of the more notable or larger companies and other employers in and around Ede are:
Plant and flower auction house Plantion (since 1 March 2010).
Advertising agency Lukkien who developed their own heliport on the roof of their office.
The Dutch headquarters of mattress and pillow manufacturer Tempur-Pedic.

column2: a foodservice distributor in Belgium and the Netherlands.

column1: The head office and two of the main datacenters of independent internet provider BIT.The world headquarters of organ manufacturer Johannus Orgelbouw.
Ede is situated along the A12 motorway and has a direct link to the A1 via the A30.
There are two railway stations in Ede: Ede-Wageningen railway station and Ede Centrum railway station. Ede-Wageningen is the main station with services to Alkmaar
Ede Centrum is served by trains from Amersfoort and Barneveld to Ede-Wageningen.
There are four secondary schools in Ede: Marnix College
column5: Ede has a university of applied sciences
column6: the Christian University of Applied Sciences Ede (Christelijke Hogeschool Ede).Recently
column7: a primary college focused on the equivalent of basic education named Technova College (formerly known as ROC A12) has been gaining interest and popularity since renovations started in 2015.

column2: in the last week of August
column3: there is a municipality-wide celebration called Heideweek (Week of the heather). It largely involves traditional Dutch festivities
column4: along with local customs. During the week
column5: a Queen of the heather and a Princess of the heather are elected from several candidates and will be the representative for the municipality of Ede on various other festivities
column6: until next year when a new queen and princess are elected.

column1: Arthur F.E. van Schendel (1910–1979) a Dutch art historian and museum director
Bert de Vries (born 1938) a retired Dutch politician and economist; lives in Bennekom
Roel Robbertsen (born 1948) a Dutch politician and pig farmer
Cees van der Knaap (born 1951) a Dutch politician; Mayor of Ede 2008 to 2017
Hans L. Bodlaender (born 1960) a Dutch computer scientist and academic
Flora Lagerwerf-Vergunst (born 1964) a Dutch judge and former politician and educator

column2: a retired football midfielder with about 430 club caps

column1: Hennie Top (born 1956) a former professional cyclist
Jaap van Lagen (born 1976) a Dutch racing driver
Diederik van Silfhout (born 1988) a dressage rider

column2: a Dutch professional tennis player; lives in Ede
